page.title: 02Local History, Warbleton
page.content: In lO86 Warbleton had land for two ploughs, and since the Conquest had fallen in value by one half. The church dates back to the l3C.Meso- lithic and Neolithic/Bronze-Age sites have been found along the rivers and from early times iron was worked in bloomeries.In the mid-l6C improved methods of iron working were imported from the Continent. Warbleton had a strong Dissenting tradition, which in the late l6C led to the use of such baptismal names as Bethankful, and after the Restoration the Quakers had a graveyard (now lost) to the north of Rushlake Green. After the decline of the iron industry in the l7C, agri- culture was carried on chiefly by small yeoman farmers. After the Napoleonic wars, many of the small farms were swallowed up by the two richest landowners-the Darbys & Dunns.
